fileIdentifier.scXML:CharacterString: Low Elevation Coast Zone (LECZ) Urban-Rural Population Estimates, Global Rural-Urban Mapping Project (GRUMP), Alpha Version

metadataStandardVersion.scXML:CharacterString: FGDC Dataset Metadata Profile -- IMGS, Version 1.0

title.scXML:CharacterString: Low Elevation Coast Zone (LECZ) Urban-Rural Population Estimates, Global Rural-Urban Mapping Project (GRUMP), Alpha Version

individualName.scXML:CharacterString: McGranahan, G., Balk , D. and Anderson, B.
Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SEDAC), Columbia University

collectiveTitle.scXML:CharacterString: The Rising Tide: Assessing the Risks of Climate Change and Human Settlements in Low Eevation Coastal Zones#

abstract.scXML:CharacterString: The Low Elevation Coastal Zone (LECZ) Urban-Rural Estimates consists of country-level estimates of urban, rural and total population and land area country-wide and in the LECZ, if applicable. Additionally, the dataset provides the number of urban extents, their population and land area that intersect the LECZ, by city-size population classifications of <100,000, 100,000 to 500,000, 500,000 to 1,000,000, 1,000,000 to 5,000,000, and 5,000,000 +. All estimates are based on GRUMP alpha data products. The LECZ was generated using SRTM Digital Elevation Model data and includes all land area that is contiguous with the coast and 10 meters or less in elevation. All grids used for population, land area, urban mask, and LECZ were of 1 km (30 arc-second) resolution. This dataset is produced by the Columbia University Center for International Earth Science Information Network (CIESIN) in collaboration with the International Institute for Environment and Development (IIED).

purpose.scXML:CharacterString: To estimate, in a globally consistent manner, urban and rural population, land area and categories of urban areas (by city-size) that are located in low elevation coastal regions that are at potential risk from sea-level rise, stronger storms and other seaward hazards induced by climate change.

otherConstraints.scXML:CharacterString: Access Constraints:CIESIN offers unrestricted access and use of data without charge, unless specified in the documentation for particular data. CIESIN also requests reprints of any publications and notification of any redistributing efforts.

orderingInstructions.scXML:CharacterString: The data and maps are available from the Socioeconomic Data and Applicaions Center (SEDAC) in Microsoft Excel (XLS), Portable Document (PDF) and Joint Photographic Experts Group (JPEG) formats via direct download at http://sedac.ciesin.columbia.edu/gpw/lecz.jsp.
